 NEW YORK (AP) - Former Mexican President Vicente Fox said Monday that the United States is letting racism dictate its policies, especially when it comes to immigration. 
 "The xenophobics, the racists, those who feel they are a superior race ... they are deciding the future of this nation," he said, without naming names, in an interview with The Associated Press.

While I do not think it's racism to arrest someone for breaking immigration laws, I do think our immigration laws are too strict. We are right in trying to reinforce border security, but we're doing it the wrong way. Our laws are restricting legal immigration to the US, but they're hardly helping solve the illegal immigrant problem. Out of the several million who apply for a green card annually, only about 50,000 actually get one. And try telling me these laws are helping when three border guards got thrown in prison for doing their job. The story that I find of particular interest, is this: one of those three guards was firing at a truck full of Mexican drug dealers; the driver was trying to run him over. One of his bullets grazed the upper lip of one of them, and for that, he got thrown in prison. The drug dealers recieved no punishment. In other words: THEY GOT AWAY SCOTT-FREE FOR ATTEMPTED HOMICIDE. After hearing this, I knew that the laws weren't stopping illegal immigrants. Legal immigrants on the other hand: unless a Mexican has a close friend or family member who is a US citizen, then he/she would have to get a degree in Engineering. Otherwise, there's no legal way for a Mexican to apply for a visa to the US, except as a tourist. If laws were always as strict as they are, very few of our ancestors would be able to immigrate to the US. Our laws are only keeping law abiding citizens out, while they don't have much effect on illegal immigration. We need to focus on keeping the "bad guys" out, not keeping the law-abiding citizens out.
